item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

I have not been into this before, but I will try.
v = 0.9c is the speed right?
1.0 ly is 1 light year?

I would think you can do it in this way:
Time for star A:
(1c - 0.9c) * x = 0.5ly

Time for star B:
(1c + 0.9c) * x = 0.5ly
The distance from the spaceship to star is 0.5 ly.
And the speed the light and spaceship approach is the speed of light ± speed of the spaceship.
When you know the time from spaceship to each start, you can find out the difference.

I don’t really know how to to this, but just doing this for fun, you should self check if this make sense.
